conclusion: Use the concept of magnetic induction and principles of electromagnetism to solve the problem.
Magnetic induction intensity B is related to current I and magnetic field strength H through the equation B = H/l.
Given: Current I is constant, length of coil l is L, mass of weight m is added to left pan, weight on right pan is balanced by current.
Consider magnetic induction intensity B before the weight is added; since current is constant, B remains constant.
Write equation for B before weight is added: B = H/l.
Consider magnetic induction intensity B after the weight is added; weight adds mass to left pan, increasing magnetic field strength H.
Write equation for B after weight is added: B = H/l.
Equate the two expressions for B: H/l = H/l.
Equation is true only if magnetic field strength H is constant.
Magnetic field strength H is related to current I and magnetic induction intensity B through equation H = B/l.
Write equation: B/l = H/l.
Equation is true only if magnetic induction intensity B is constant.
Magnetic induction intensity B is related to current I and magnetic field strength H through equation B = H/l.
Write equation: H/l = H/l.
Equation is true only if magnetic field strength H is constant.
Magnetic field strength H is related to current I and magnetic induction intensity B through equation H = B/l.
Write equation: B/l = H/l.
Equation is true only if magnetic induction intensity B is constant.
Magnetic induction intensity B is related to current I and magnetic field strength H through equation B = H/l.
Write equation: H/l = H/l.
Equation is true only if magnetic field strength H is constant.
Magnetic field strength H is related to current I and magnetic induction intensity B through equation H = B/l.
Write equation: B/l = H/l.
